Directions: Fill a cocktail shaker with ice. Pour in the gin, lemon juice, simple syrup and a dash of bitters. Cover and shake until the outside of the container is frosty, about 15 seconds. Strain into a highball glass full of ice. Top off with club soda and garnish with a lemon slice and maraschino cherry.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "This is a great warm weather cocktail with or without the splash of bitters."

Directions: Measure the orange juice and vodka into a shaker and add a scoop of ice. Cover and shake until the outside is frosty. Strain into a glass and serve.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "Remember those creamy orange ice pops you had as a kid? Now you can drink it too! You can adjust the vodka to your liking. It goes down smooth, so watch your consumption."

Ingredients: 1/2 (1.5 fluid ounce) jigger full-flavored gin such as Tanqueray or Plymouth
Directions: Drink or pour out the beer to the level at which the neck widens, making room for the other ingredients. Pour in the gin and lemon juice. Secure the opening of the bottle using your thumb and gently rock the bottle to mix the ingredients. Drink and enjoy.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "A cocktail made from Mexican beer, gin and lemon juice. The ingredients complement each other: the beer smooths the gin, and the gin/lemon de-fizzes the beer. Make sure everything is cold before preparing. More is not better: Using more than a half shot of gin or lemon will ruin the flavor. Gins vary widely in flavor. While other gins can be used, the original gin used by the creator is Tanqueray. Don't use lime as a substitute for lemon."

Directions: Pour the orange vodka, raspberry vodka, pineapple schnapps, grenadine, sour mix, pineapple juice, and cranberry juice into a cocktail shaker over ice. Cover, and shake until the outside of the shaker has frosted. Pour into a highball glass, and garnish with a maraschino cherry and orange slice to serve.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "A great tropical drink!"

Directions: In a tall glass filled with ice, combine vodka, rum, tequila and triple sec. Top with equal parts sweet-and-sour and cola. Squeeze juice of lemon wedge and lime wedge over top; stir.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "The Texas part of the tea comes from the tequila as opposed to a Long Island iced tea, which uses gin instead of tequila. This is the standard Bartender's recipe for a Texas Tea."

Directions: Combine vodka, schnapps, and crushed ice in a shaker. Shake vigorously to chill. Pour into martini glass, garnish with dried apple, and serve.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "I just got taken back to the beach boardwalk after trying this little concoction."

Ingredients: 1/2 teaspoon brandy-based orange liqueur (such as Grand Marnier®)
Directions: Muddle the crushed ice and cranberry sauce in a rocks glass until the ice has been tinged red. Pour in the whiskey, orange liqueur, bitters, and water. Stir and serve.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "We drink this year-round but invented it over the holidays, when we had mounds of homemade cranberry sauce in the fridge. It evolved from a Champagne and fresh berry compote drink that we saw being made at Portland's Clyde Common. We subbed bourbon and experimented until we arrived at this delicious mix."

Ingredients: 1 (1.5 fluid ounce) jigger tequila (such as Jose Cuervo®)
1/2 fluid ounce coffee-flavored liqueur (such as Trader Vic's®)
Directions: Pour tequila and coffee-flavored liqueur into a shaker filled with ice; cover and shake until chilled. Strain drink into a martini glass. Garnish with a maraschino cherry.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "A mix of tequila and coffee liqueur that produces a unbelievable and not-too-sweet exotic drink. You will have to give this a try, even if you aren't fond of tequila!"

Directions: Place 2 ice cubes in a cocktail shaker; add passion fruit-flavored syrup, pineapple juice, lime juice, dark rum, and light rum. Cover shaker and shake.
Fill a 14-ounce glass with remaining ice and strain drink over ice.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "Our version of the Mardi Gras favorite isn't too sweet or too big. It's just right."

Directions: Mix the tequila, blue curacao liqueur, and lime juice in a 2-cup measuring cup, and pour over ice in a margarita pitcher. If preferred, pour into a blender with ice, blend to a slush, and serve in a margarita glasses.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "Don't ask how I came by this recipe. I prefer not to coat rim with salt, but that's optional."

Directions: In a cocktail mixer full of ice, combine Chartreuse and rum. Shake vigorously and strain into 2 shot glasses.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "!!!Alcohol!!! For those of you who like to drink a shot to get the evening going...Well I've got one for ya..."

Directions: In a cocktail mixer, shake together the Blue Curacao, coconut rum, vodka and grenadine. Pour into a champagne flute, and fill glass with champagne.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "A noble drink concocted of Blue Curacao, coconut rum, vodka and champagne. Kinda sweet."

Ingredients: 1 (15 ounce) can cream of coconut (such as Coco Lopez®)
3/4 cup tequila (such as Sauza® 100% Blue Agave)
1/4 cup brandy-based orange liqueur (such as Grand Marnier®)
Directions: Blend cream of coconut, ice, tequila, lime juice, and orange liqueur in a blender until smooth.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "A refreshing cross between a margarita and a pina colada!"

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons white sugar, or as needed (optional)
Directions: Blend ice, rum, lime juice, triple sec, and 1 teaspoon sugar in a blender on the highest setting until smooth, 15 to 20 seconds. Pour into glass.
Spread 2 tablespoons sugar in a thin layer onto a small plate. Rub lime wedge around the rim of a glass. Dip glass rim in sugar to coat. Pour blended beverage into the prepared glass to serve.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "Enjoy this classic daiquiri frozen or on the rocks."

Ingredients: 1/2 fluid ounce orange-flavored liqueur (such as Cointreau®), or to taste
1 teaspoon orange juice, or to taste
Directions: Place ice cubes in a cocktail shaker; top with blood orange juice, vodka, and orange-flavored liqueur. Cover shaker and shake; strain drink into a martini glass. Top drink with orange juice and garnish with lime wedge.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "This is a refreshing version of a cosmopolitan martini using blood oranges."

Directions: Place ice in a cocktail shaker. Pour in vermouth and whiskey; add bitters. Shake and strain into a chilled martini glass; garnish with lemon twist.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "The Manhattan gets schooled; this is a dry Manhattan, essentially. It calls for dry, not sweet, vermouth and orange bitters instead of Angostura."

Ingredients: 8 fluid ounces stout beer (such as Guinness®)
1 fluid ounce Irish cream liqueur (such as Bailey's®)
1/2 fluid ounce Irish whiskey (such as Jameson®)
Directions: Pour beer into a pint glass. Pour Irish cream and Irish whiskey into a shot glass. Gently drop the shot glass into the glass of beer.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "This classic St. Patrick's Day drink is simply a shot glass filled with Irish cream and Irish whiskey, dropped into a glass of stout beer. The combination of the three will knock you off your feet!"

Directions: Combine gin and vermouth in a cocktail mixing class. Add ice and stir until chilled. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with pearl onions.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "A variation on the classic martini, the Gibson mixes gin and dry vermouth together and garnishes the cocktail with a cocktail onion."

Directions: Combine rum and ginger beer in an old-fashioned glass. Add ice and stir.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "Popular within the sailing community, the dark 'n' stormy is also the national drink of Bermuda. The simple mixture of dark rum and ginger beer makes for a great cocktail in any weather."

Directions: Place martini glasses in the freezer to frost.
Fill chilled glass with ice, and pour in ginger liqueur. Allow liqueur to chill for one minute. Remove ice cubes, and pour in vodka. Garnish with crystallized ginger.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "A vodka martini with a bit of a twist and kick. Ideally, you should have chilled martini glasses ahead of time, as this removes the need to chill the glasses when you prepare. Store the vodka in the freezer as well. If your glass and vodka are not chilled, you can make this drink in a cocktail shaker. Don't shake for too long - the vodka will become watery."

Ingredients: 1 (1.5 fluid ounce) jigger creme de cacao
Directions: Pour the chocolate liqueur, creme de cacao, vodka, and creamer into a cocktail shaker over ice. Cover, and shake until the outside of the shaker has frosted. Dip the rim of a chilled martini glass in chocolate syrup. Strain the cocktail into the glass to serve.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "This sweet and creamy martini is rich enough to be considered a dessert."

Directions: In a mixing glass, combine vodka, Scotch, gin and chicken broth. Mix well and serve over crushed ice. Garnish with a sprig of mint.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "Sit back, relax and enjoy this comforting old Southern libation."

Ingredients: 1 tablespoon whipped cream, or to taste
Directions: Fill a glass 1/2-full with ice. Pour pumpkin spice-flavored liqueur and vanilla-flavored vodka over ice; top with half-and-half. Stir drink with cinnamon stick and garnish with whipped cream and pumpkin pie spice.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "This makes for a festive-looking, delicious holiday after-dinner drink at Thanksgiving and Christmas. Nice addition at Halloween parties too!"

Directions: Fill a tall glass with ice cubes. Pour in the vodka, pineapple juice, cranberry juice, a splash of orange juice and a splash of carbonated water. Add a quick squeeze of fresh lemon and lime. Stir and garnish with wedges of lemon and lime.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "I was just experimenting on day with some vodka and a whole bunch of fruit juices and came up with this wonderful summer drink. Garnish with lemon and lime wedges."

Ingredients: 1 (1.5 fluid ounce) jigger triple sec liqueur
1 (1.5 fluid ounce) jigger fresh lime juice
Directions: In a blender, combine the tequila, triple sec, lime juice, mango, and ice. Blend until ice is finely crushed. Sweeten with mango nectar to your liking.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "Authentic south of the border Mango Margaritas."

Ingredients: 1 (12 fluid ounce) can frozen pink lemonade concentrate, thawed
3 fluid ounces lemon-flavored rum (such as Bacardi Limon®)
Directions: Mix pink lemonade concentrate, vodka, rum, lime juice, and sugar substitute together in a pitcher. Add beer slowly; stir gently. Serve over ice.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "Delicious but very dangerous cocktail for a group."

Directions: Combine pomegranate juice, cranberry juice, raspberry vodka, orange-flavored liqueur, grenadine syrup, and crushed ice in a shaker. Shake vigorously to chill. Pour into martini glasses, and serve.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "I ordered this martini at a chain restaurant which we don't have in our area when I was visiting family out of town. I tried one, and fell in love with it. So I wrote down the ingredients and starting playing around with the measurements. I found the perfect amount and it tastes even better than the one at the restaurant! I have used Sugar Free Cranberry Juice with this and it has turned out great!"

Directions: Puree blueberries, sugar, and red wine vinegar in a blender. Add peppercorns. Chill shrub, covered, 4 hours to 2 days. Strain.
In a cocktail shaker half-filled with ice, combine 2 fluid ounces blueberry shrub and bourbon. Shake until very cold.
Strain into an ice-filled pint glass. Top with ginger beer. Garnish with additional blueberries or a lime wedge.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "This drink starts with a simple shrub--a tart, fruity liquid you make ahead and can also sip straight up or with seltzer."

Directions: Place the strawberry basil leaves, and sugar into a cocktail shaker, and mash well with a cocktail muddler. Add half of the ice to the cocktail shaker, and place the rest into a tall glass. Pour in the gin and lemon juice, cover, and shake until the outside of the shaker has frosted. Strain into the chilled glass over the ice, top with the club soda, and stir to serve.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "I served this cocktail for the first time at a wedding shower and it was a hit! Since then I make it whenever strawberries are in season. I have substituted raspberries when I had them on hand and it was great!"

Directions: Combine the simple syrup, lemon juice and whiskey in a shaker. Fill with ice. Cover and shake for about 30 seconds, until the shaker is frosty. Strain into martini glasses and garnish with a maraschino cherry. This can also be served in tumblers full of ice.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "If it's not made from scratch, it ain't a Whiskey Sour. For a cleaner, classier looking drink, strain the lemon juice to remove seeds and pulp."

cocktails.Recipe Name: Nectar of the Gods - A Champagne Beverage
Ingredients: 1 (1.5 fluid ounce) jigger raspberry-flavored liqueur (such as Chambord®)
4 fluid ounces champagne, or as needed
Directions: Stir raspberry-flavored liqueur and agave nectar together in a tall, thin-sided glass using a spoon. Tilt the glass at an angle and pour in champagne.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "A nice easy champagne variation with a Southwestern twist."

Ingredients: 2 cups tomato and clam juice cocktail (such as Clamato®)
1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce, or to taste
1 tablespoon prepared horseradish, or to taste
2 teaspoons finely ground black pepper, or to taste
1 1/2 teaspoons hot pepper sauce (such as Tabasco®), or to taste
1 teaspoon celery salt, or to taste
1 lime, cut into wedges, or as needed
Directions: Combine vodka, tomato juice, tomato and clam juice, lemon juice, lime juice, Worcestershire sauce, horseradish, black pepper, pepper sauce, and celery salt in a large pitcher. Add ice and pour cocktail into glasses; serve each with a lime wedge.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "Al was my stepdad, who was a wonderful man and a great cook! One of his specialties was his Bloody Mary, and no matter how many pitchers he prepared for company, they always wanted more. My only modification has been to add a bit of horseradish. This is a great brunch beverage, but various friends always ask if I'll please make 'Al's Bloodys' when they come for dinner."

Directions: Fill a highball glass with 1 1/2 cups ice and set aside.
Combine tequila and orange juice in a cocktail mixing glass. Add 1 cup ice, stir, and strain into the prepared highball glass. Slowly pour in grenadine and let settle.
Stir before drinking.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "The two-toned, sunrise-like appearance of this cocktail makes it as welcome on a cool day as it is on a hot day."

Directions: Mix orange juice, daiquiri mixer, lemon-lime soda, and vodka together in a pitcher.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "My friend, Jane, shared this recipe at our Christmas Bash 2014. It was enjoyed by all. It is very simple to make this recipe as an adult version or a kid-friendly version. Serve over ice. Cheers!"

Directions: Combine rum, lime juice, and honey syrup in a cocktail shaker. Add ice, cover and shake until chilled. Strain into Champagne flute. Top with Champagne.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "The air mail cocktail quite simply, can transport you. The combination of rum and Champagne is as refreshing as it is sophisticated."

Ingredients: 1 (12 fluid ounce) can frozen limeade concentrate
12 fluid ounces tequila (measure with empty limeade can)
margarita or kosher salt for the rims
Directions: Working in 2 batches, place 1 quart ice cubes in a blender. Add 1/2 can limeade, 6 ounces tequila and 2 tablespoons Cointreau. Blend at highest speed until drink is almost smooth. Pour into a pitcher and repeat with remaining ingredients. Store in the freezer.

To salt the margarita glasses, pour a single layer of salt on a salad plate. Moisten each glass rim with lime; dip each rim in the salt. Pour margaritas into each glass; garnish with lime. Serve immediately.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "Authentic margaritas call for lots of fresh lime juice - both expensive and time-consuming. I've found I can shortcut the process by using frozen limeade. And for a festive non-alcoholic drink, combine a 12-ounce can of limeade (thawed) with a 48-ounce bottle of sparkling water."

Ingredients: 1 tablespoon Kahlua or other coffee flavored liqueur
1 tablespoon brandy-based orange liqueur (such as Grand Marnier®)
Directions: Carefully pour coffee liqueur, Grand Marnier, and Irish cream liqueur into a cordial glass so that they do not mix.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "I used to work as a bartender, and noticed that Christine was looking for a recipe for the B52 Bomber on the allrecipes.com recipe exchange. A subtle blend of coffee, orange, and Irish cream create a memorable and festive cordial."

Ingredients: 1 cup ice cubes, or as needed
1 fluid ounce orange-flavored liqueur (such as Cointreau®)
1 fluid ounce raspberry-flavored liqueur (such as Chambord®)
Directions: Fill a cocktail shaker with ice; add champagne, orange-flavored liqueur, and raspberry-flavored liqueur. Cover shaker, shake, and strain drink into a martini glass.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "The perfect cocktail for anyone who wants to feel like a duchess."

Ingredients: 1/2 fluid ounce coffee-flavored liqueur (such as Kahlua®)
1/2 fluid ounce Irish cream liqueur (such as Bailey's®)
Directions: Pour coffee liqueur into a shot glass. Carefully pour in Irish cream liqueur so it floats on top. Pour triple sec on top so it floats as well, to create a three-layered drink.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "This layered shot will, quite frankly, get you bombed."

Directions: Wet the rim of a chilled martini glass with water, and dip into the crushed candy cane. Pour the vodka, schnapps, and half-and-half into a cocktail shaker over ice. Cover, and shake until the outside of the shaker has frosted. Strain into the rimmed martini glass, and garnish with candy cane to serve.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "This is the perfect after-holiday-shopping martini!"

Directions: Fill a highball glass with ice, and pour in the pineapple juice, rum, vanilla schnapps, and triple sec. Stir to mix, and garnish with lime and maraschino cherries to serve.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "I sometimes substitute grapefruit juice for the pineapple juice and/or vodka for the rum. Try every combination 'till the sun rises!"

Directions: Mix lime juice and vodka together in a shaker until blended. Pour into a glass filled with ice; top with lemon zest.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "A recipe from my Grandma Briere who was a bartender for 30 years. Original price for this drink in the 70's was $1.00."

Directions: Wash lemon very well and cut into fine slices. Put in a gallon jar with sugar. Mince pineapple and put in jar. Pour in wine and soda. Mix with a spoon and refrigerate for 2 hours.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "This recipe is excellent for very hot days!"

Ingredients: 1 fluid ounce orange-flavored liqueur (such as Cointreau®)
Directions: Sprinkle sugar on a small plate. Lightly wet half the rim of of a coupe glass with a damp paper towel. Dip the moistened rim in sugar to coat. Set the glass in the refrigerator to chill.
Combine Cognac, orange-flavored liqueur, and lemon juice in a cocktail shaker. Add ice, cover, and shake until chilled. Strain into the chilled, sugar-rimmed coupe.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "The Ritz Hotel in Paris claims to have created this cocktail in the early 20th century. The potent combination of Cognac and orange-flavored liqueur shaken until ice cold with lemon juice is a timeless classic."

Ingredients: 20 limes, juiced, or more to taste
25 fluid ounces sparkling water, or more to taste
Directions: Combine sugar and mint leaves in a pitcher; mash well with a cocktail muddler. Stir in lime juice and rum until sugar is dissolved. Stir in sparkling water.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "Most mixed drink recipes are for individual drinks but this recipe is great for a small group. When I need to mix the recipe in advance, I mix everything but the sparkling water, which can be added right before serving. It's a delicious and refreshing recipe, perfect for a summer dinner party or back yard barbeque. Serve over ice and garnish with a sprig of mint and/or slice of lime."

Ingredients: 2 fluid ounces ginger ale, or to taste
Directions: Fill a tall cocktail glass with ice. Stir in whiskey and ginger ale.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "The spicy snap of the ginger and rye whiskey together make a super simple cocktail seem complex."

Directions: In a highball glass over ice, combine gin, grapefruit juice and salt. Stir well.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "This simple salty concoction is made with gin, grapefruit juice and salt."

Directions: Place ice in a blender and crush for 15 to 20 seconds. Add frozen strawberries, tequila, triple sec, and limeade. Blend until smooth.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "We serve these when friends come over and they are always sure to liven up a party!"

Ingredients: 1/2 cup ice cubes, or as needed, divided
1 lime, zested in thin strips and quartered
2 fluid ounces fresh Key lime juice
2 fluid ounces vodka (such as Hangar One®)
Directions: Fill ice into cocktail glass and place in the freezer.
Place 2 lime wedges and the sugar cube into a cocktail shaker and mash well with a cocktail muddler. Pour in ice, lime juice, and vodka, cover, and shake until the outside of the shaker has frosted.
Remove ice from cocktail glass; wipe dry with a paper towel. Rub a lime wedge around the rim of the glass. Strain the contents into the chilled glass and garnish with a twist of lime zest.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "I like my drinks sour. Not like sour mix sour, actually sour. Nice and tart. And this really fits the bill. And, while it looks complicated (juice all those lime?! Really?), the results are worth it."

Directions: Pour the frozen limeade concentrate, tequila, triple sec, lime juice, lime zest, and sugar into a blender, and blend until thoroughly mixed. Serve in glasses over ice. If preferred, add ice cubes to margarita mix in the blender, and blend until slushy; pour into glasses.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "Awesome margaritas that pack a punch! I prefer mine over ice without salt on the rim."

Directions: Stir the orange juice, pineapple juice, simple syrup, coconut-flavored rum, 151 proof rum, grenadine syrup, and fruit-flavored liqueur together in a 2-quart or larger pitcher. Refrigerate at least 2 hours, or overnight.
Place 1 cup of crushed ice in each of eight 12-ounce glasses. Pour about 1 cup of the rum mixture into each glass, and garnish each with a maraschino cherry and an orange slice.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "This is a flavorful summertime party drink."

Directions: Fill a highball glass with ice, pour in vodka and peach schnapps, then fill glass with half orange juice and half cranberry juice.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "A refreshing cocktail of Vodka, peach schnapps, cranberry and orange juice. Can be served over ice as a drink or strained into a shot or martini glass."

Directions: Fill a shaker half way full with ice. Pour in the lemonade, club soda and sugar. Cut the lemon in half and squeeze the juice into the shaker. Pour in the vodka, cover and shake well. Strain into two glasses that are filled half way with ice. You can add oranges and cherries for garnish and make your drink look real pretty but hey, do you really want to do all that after work? Enjoy!
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "Here's a cool and refreshing way to wind down after a hard days work!"

Ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces Brie cheese, or more to taste
1 cup ice cubes, or as needed
1 dash Worcestershire sauce, or to taste
1/2 ounce wedge Stilton cheese, or as desired
Directions: Combine rum, triple sec, pickled chutney, and Brie cheese in a blender; pulse 1 or 2 times to combine. Add ice cubes and blend until drink is slushy, 1 to 2 minutes. Pour drink into a martini glass; top with Worcestershire sauce and garnish glass with Stilton cheese wedge.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "This deliciously sweet and tangy cocktail is perfect for brunch and those wanting an alternative to a bloody Mary."

Ingredients: 2 fluid ounces sweet and sour mix
Directions: In a tall glass full of ice, pour rum, coconut rum, banana liqueur and blackberry brandy. Fill glass with sour mix and orange juice, then top with a dash of grenadine. Garnish with wedges of orange and lime.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "This is a fruity version of a Rum Runner that always brings people back for more!"

Ingredients: 1 (1.5 fluid ounce) jigger fruit-flavored rum liqueur
4 fluid ounces lemon-lime flavored carbonated beverage
Directions: Fill a tall glass with ice. Pour in rum liqueur and vodka. Fill with lemon-lime soda.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "This is a drink that a friend and I made up one night while I was tending bar at a local private club."

cocktails.Recipe Name: Don's Friend Tonja's Cousin Toni's Boyfriend's Grandmother's Eggnog
Ingredients: 2 teaspoons ground nutmeg, or amount to taste
Directions: In a large bowl, beat the eggs and sugar with an electric mixer until thick and pale, about 5 minutes. Gradually stir in the bourbon, rum, half and half and nutmeg.

In a separate chilled bowl, whip the cream until it can stand in a peak. Fold the whipped cream into the egg mixture. Pour into a plastic container and refrigerate overnight (if possible). Shake the container before serving.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "Tonja was born in the 1940's and this is her cousin Toni's boyfriend's grandmother's eggnog, so I'm guessing this is from the mid-1800's and probably dates much earlier. The original recipe called for half milk and half cream, but I use half and half. Delicious and simple, but be warned, Granny apparently liked a kick! I've made it from scratch and with the modern equivalents and it's fantastic either way. Do yourself a favor and use a mixer for everything. Those who like eggnog LOVE this recipe. I never leave a party with leftovers."

Directions: Combine vodka, coffee liqueur, cream, and crushed ice in a cocktail shaker. Shake vigorously to chill. Pour into martini glasses, and serve.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "Enjoy a delightful martini with taste but not too sweet!!!"

Ingredients: 1 cup ice cubes, or as needed
Directions: Mix wine, lemon-lime soda, peach schnapps, and pineapple juice in a cocktail shaker; add ice. Stir until wine mixture is chilled.
Place frozen peach, red grapes, and green grapes in a martini glass; strain wine mixture into martini glass.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "An adaptation of a similar recipe from one of those chain restaurants. This may be served over the rocks, if desired. Using lemon-lime seltzer instead of lemon-lime soda makes the drink less sweet. Simply refreshing!"

Ingredients: 1 (1.5 fluid ounce) jigger coffee flavored liqueur
1 (12 fluid ounce) can or bottle cola-flavored carbonated beverage
Directions: Fill a tall 16 ounce glass 1/3 full of crushed ice. Pour in the vodka and coffee liqueur. Fill to within 1 inch of the rim with cola. Fill to within 1/2 inch with light cream. Stir to blend.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "A delicious blend accented with coffee liqueur."

Ingredients: 1 (8 ounce) can canned pineapple chunks, undrained
1 (6 ounce) can frozen orange juice concentrate
Directions: In a blender, combine pineapple, orange juice concentrate with juice, rum, sugar, lime juice and ice cubes. Blend until smooth. Pour into glasses, garnish with cherries, and serve.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "This drink is really refreshing on a hot summer day, however, only adults are allowed to indulge in this feast!"

Ingredients: 3 fluid ounces Prosecco (such as Caposaldo DOC)
1/2 fluid ounce orange-flavored liqueur (such as Cointreau®)
Directions: Pour mango juice, Prosecco, and orange liqueur into a blender in the order listed; add ice. Blend until smooth. Pour into a serving glass. Garnish with mint.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "A crazy refreshing bomb of mango flavor and Prosecco! Garnish with fresh mango if preferred."

Directions: Pour absinthe into a champagne glass. Gradually add sparkling wine.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "Named after Hemingway's book about bullfighting. But even so, I wouldn't try drinking this cocktail until evening."

Ingredients: 1 (1.5 fluid ounce) jigger deluxe Canadian whiskey
Directions: Fill a tall glass with ice. Pour in the whiskey and amaretto, then fill to the top with cranberry juice. Stir and enjoy.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "I created this with some co-workers when I used to tend bar. It's quite refreshing."

cocktails.Recipe Name: Crazy Casey's Long Island Spiced Tea
Directions: Stir together the sugar, water, lime juice, lemon juice, rum, tequila, vodka, gin, and triple sec in a glass until the sugar has dissolved. Add the ice, and pour in the cola; garnish with the lemon wedge to serve.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "A traditional Long Island Iced tea with a little more island spice!"

Ingredients: 2 fluid ounces spiced rum (such as Captain Morgan's®)
Directions: Place the mint leaves, lime wedges, and ice into a cocktail shaker; mash well with a cocktail muddler. Pour in the simple syrup, lime juice, rum, cranberry juice, and soda water. Cover, and shake until the outside of the shaker has frosted. Strain into a chilled glass to serve.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "A friend of mine and I were trying to make use of spiced rum and this is our new favorite drink!"

Ingredients: 1 (1.5 fluid ounce) jigger vanilla flavored vodka (such as Stoli®)
1 (1.5 fluid ounce) jigger Irish cream liqueur (such as Bailey's®)
1 (1.5 fluid ounce) jigger pumpkin flavored liqueur (such as Hiram Walker®)
Directions: Pour the vanilla flavored vodka, Irish cream liqueur, and pumpkin flavored liqueur into a cocktail shaker over ice. Cover, and shake until the outside of the shaker has frosted. Strain into a chilled martini glass, and garnish with a sprinkle of ground cinnamon and ground nutmeg to serve.
cocktails.Chef Remarks: "A fun, delicious cocktail for your next holiday gathering. A good friend shared this great idea!"
